Sent: Tuesday, June 9, 2015 10:56 AM
To: X L
Subject: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear X,

I also heard the news after I told you this movie, I feel sorry for it, especially after seeing what he has suffered from his mental illness and how they faced it together...

Although I'm a little afraid of the sadness that may come after watch "Amour", I sure I will do it someday, since I don't see sad as an emotion we should avoid. I still remember that in my high school, I watched a movie which has a very tragic ending, I was depressed for several days, everything seemed hopeless to me , even my friend found out there was something wrong with me, and asked me what happened :-) Now, I have to laugh when recalling this. Yes, now, I still get heartbreaking for the books I read, the movies I watched, however, I won't feel hopeless anymore, contrarily, I see it as a way to make us cherish what we have. Speaking of high school, I really don't like most of part of it. Yes, sometimes we got good moments, but most of time it seemed like everything we did is just for passing the university entrance exam (高考), and it is a exam really boring :-( We repeat the same thing everything, which now I feel like wasting of time and life. Ok, I shouldn't be so negative, like what I've just said, I really cherish the life I have now, doing the things I like :-)

Yesterday, I received the email, they told me I will teach "Analysis" next semester, it contains both lecture and seminar, so there are much to prepare I suppose. Ok, now I will say, See you tomorrow :-D

Best,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Dimanche 7 Juin 2015 21:09:15
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear R,

thank you for your encouraging words about teaching, that's very kind of you :-)

You don't have to watch "Amour" if you don't want to, I can perfectly understand your feelings. In my case, I watched the movie by chance, I haven't read about it before, so there was no courage involved, only naivety :-D About heartbreaking stories, do you know the Japanese writer Banana Yoshimoto? (Banana is not her real name.) I read Kitchen and Moonlight Shadow by her. These are really moving and heartbreaking. The first story still gave me the feeling of some hope, while the second one just made me sad...

Coming back to movies, I watched "A Beautiful Mind" yesterday. What can I say? I knew a bit about Nash's mathematical achievements, but I didn't know about his mental illness. I'm impressed that in spite of his sufferings, he became such a great mathematician! Or maybe the illness and his ingenuity were connected, maybe it was his illness which allowed him to do things normal people would never be able to do. Anyway, it seems like a very high price to pay. Nash must have been a special character, in positive and negative ways. I learned that he and his wife died in a car accident this month, coming home from Norway where he received the Abel Prize. Tragic, isn't it?

Yes, that's great, you can call me via Skype on Wednesday, at 20:00 local time in France (which is 19:00 London time). It's a good time for me. So I'll just wait for you, and make sure that I'm online and logged into Skype.

Best wishes,
X

From: r.x@e.fr <r.x@e.fr>
Sent: Saturday, June 6, 2015 6:19 PM
To: X L
Subject: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear X,

Thank you for your stories, the negative one and the positive one. Reading about that you just seat there and got trembling after your first lecture, it makes me laugh, since it reminds me of my same experience last year when I did my oral defense for master thesis :-) I'm sure you learned a lot from last year, asking questions is a good way to keep attention up, that's the way I expected my teacher to do when I was undergraduate. And the beauty, the importance of the proofs, that requires more understanding or admiring of what you teach, not everyone can do that, so I guess that's reason you get the positive feedback this year :-) Ah, you have got a student? I must say congratulations to you! Perhaps you can tell more about it when I call you? I'm wondering maybe I will call you in skype Wednesday night to say Gute Reise to you:-), around eight clock( in France), is that Ok for you?

In fact, I knew "Amour" because I saw a short review of someone, it writes also the main two parts in the film, the love and the pain. When facing the subject like illness and age, I always feel fragile, so I'm not sure I won't be overwhelmed by the heartbreaking seeing this film, that's the reason why I haven't watched it yet. It really needs courage :-)

Best wishes,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Sat, 06 Jun 2015 00:28:02 +0200 (CEST)
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear R,

yes, absolutely, feedback is very important. If it's positive, then that's nice, but if it's negative (and honest), then we can actually learn even more. For instance, last year, my teaching was not so good. It was my first time teaching in the UK, and I was not familiar with the material of the module. So I focused on giving good lectures, explaining all the proofs in detail. For those students who paid attention, it was fine, but quite a few got bored and even started to get noisy; also, students were afraid of the proofs, especially in the exam. This year, I changed things a bit. Not the material of the module, and I also did all the proofs, but I would ask questions during my lectures to keep the attention up, and I would summarize the ideas of very long proofs. I even spent half an hour to discuss the importance, and also the beauty, of proofs. These little changes made quite a difference. I think that teaching or giving talks is a matter of practice and experience. I remember quite well the first talk I gave in our research seminar. I did a lot of preparations, and was quite nervous. And after the talk, I sat for hours in my room, my hands still trembling from the agitation :-) Thinking back, I have to laugh about myself, because in the meantime, I gave lots of talks, and feel more confident about it. So the first time may not be easy, but once you started to teach, I am sure you will get more and more confident.

Yes, I remember the scene. And I had to smile that you went to the restaurant and watched the sea. I don't think it's stupid, because that's exactly the sort of thing I can imagine myself doing :-) The only problem is that New Zealand is quite far away :-D And yes, I like "Amour". It's touching in both ways, in a nice way when you see the couple's love, but also in a heartbreaking way when you see their pain... Yes, yes, I won't say more, since you want to watch the movie :-)

If you were my PhD student, then I would be facing the following problem: On the one hand, I would want the best for you, which means that I would have to be very strict and demanding, but on the other hand, I would be afraid of making you unhappy, or that you would be angry with me. So in the end, I probably wouldn't know what to do at all ;-) More seriously, I still have to learn at lot when it comes to supervising PhD students. Actually, I just got a new student this week; we had our first meeting three days ago.

By the way, I'm going to Germany next Thursday, to visit family and for a conference. Would you like to skype before I go? I'd be available anytime you like, just let me know.

Best wishes,
X

From: r.x@e.fr <r.x@e.fr>
Sent: Thursday, June 4, 2015 9:06 PM
To: X L
Subject: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear X,

It's funny, but truly sometimes if we get some feedback from others, it really encourges us, although we don't do it for rewards at the first time. And I think maybe the happiness as a teacher is to know that you really help them to do well, I'm happy to read that your students like you, perhaps it's because you do have made wonderful lectures :-) If I were few years younger, maybe I would choose you as my Ph.D. superviser :-D Hmm... Q won't be happy to hear this, haha. More seriously, I'm still not sure if I can get the chance to teach next semester, but if I get, there is still much to prepare during this summer I suppose, since I've never tried before.

"The Intouchables", in fact, I like this movie very much, but I didn't notice its music, I should have paid more attention, since now, I find them quite good. Two people who have totally different backgrounds , but they are a really perfect couple, maybe just because they both know how to respect the others. Do you remember in the end of film, the scene when the man finally meets his penfriend in a restaurant and the scenery seen from their table? The beach and the wave... They are quite impressive for me, then I found out that it is shot at the coast of Cabourg. So last year, I went to that place, found the restaurant in the movie and watched the sea from the same angle :-)It sounds a little stupide, but anyway, it's quite wonderful! Perhaps, one day, you can also experience the scenery in Lord of ring in New Zealand :-)

I heard about "Amour" before, but I haven't seen yet, since you like, I will see it.

Best wishes,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Mercredi 3 Juin 2015 22:34:07
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear R,

awesome, that's great news! Thanks for letting me know about your bookings, and I wish you good luck in Paris, let's hope that everything will be fine. If you need to take a local train, to Reading or somewhere else, we can always buy tickets during your visit, that's easy. And yes, I also want to see you again, I want it sooo much :-) Is it really only a month since we've met in Wuhan? I really have to force myself not to think about you all the time, because that only makes the waiting time pass even more slowly :-(

I just finished checking today. Not only do we have to mark our own exams, but we also have to check the ones of our colleagues. That just means going through the scripts and making sure that the points add up correctly, and that the examiner has not overlooked something. When I said that marking is terrible, then checking is even worse. It's so boring and monotonous, you just have to turn pages and add up numbers, like a calculator. But it has to be done. Anyway, it's over now. Maybe I shouldn't be so negative, since teaching my module this year was actually quite nice. My students were pretty good, at least that was my impression. And it's very rewarding to see students do well! There was one student who shook my hand and told me that it was an honour to be taught be me, he did that twice, and every time we meet he always greets me with a big smile and waves :-D And yesterday, a group of students came to my office to thank me for the teaching :-) So, yes, if you could do a bit of teaching, I think that would be a good experience.

Just as you say, Sissel's voice is like an angel. Very beautiful. Enya's voice also is like that. I first heard Enya in "Lord of the Rings". These are epic movies. Particularly impressive is the scenery, they filmed in New Zealand. I've never been there, but that's definitely a place I'd like to go. New Zealand and Australia must simply be beautiful. Ludovico Enaudi's music appears in the movie "The Intouchables", that's a French movie about a person in a wheelchair and a guy who takes care of him. It's quite moving to see how they help each other. Talking about French movies, I recently saw "Amour", also a very touching movie about a couple who loves each other until a very old age. Do you know it?

Wonderful, that rainbow was a very nice welcoming present for you in B! And now I also have a beautiful picture in my mind, the rainbow with its bright colours, the fresh air after the rain, the rays of sunshine breaking through the clouds, ..., and you, admiring the beauty of the rainbow, trying to touch it...

Best wishes,
X

From: r.x@e.fr <r.x@e.fr>
Sent: Tuesday, June 2, 2015 11:28 PM
To: X L
Subject: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear X,

I'm happy that I'm quite efficient tonight, I have accomplished the applying procedures on the internet and booked all the tickets I need for application. Concerning the ticket to Reading, because after I told my friend that I get a chance to meet her, she prefers maybe go somewhere else near London with me instead of Reading, and she still haven't made her mind yet. My appointment in Paris will be at next Friday, hope everything will be fine. If nothing goes wrong, I will arrive London st-Pancras at 15h30 23th August. Writing about this makes me excited again, I can't wait to see you again:-)

Humm, it's a good question...You don't know since I have made a mistake! :-):-), ok, the thing should be when I watched Titanic, the fascinating vocal during the movie made me obsessed, I looked it up, it's devoted by Sissel, so then I get many other her pieces, "should it matter" is one of my favorites. Moreover, I'm very happy to know that you use the Canon to wake you up every day, because it is a music we both like, and that's indeed a wonderful start of a day.

Speaking of the rainbow after the rain, I still remember the experience when I saw a rainbow the first time after I arrived B. That may be the most wonderful rainbow I have ever seen, it had exactly seven colors, every one of them is so bright, and it seemed so closed, and I felt that I can even touch it by my hand! I have been to the sea for a few times, but I never got to the chance to see a sunset or sunrise. Now I have got a beautiful image in my mind, siting near the plage, waiting for sun to get it's head out, quietly...

Best,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Lundi 1 Juin 2015 20:38:08
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear R,

I really had to smile when I read your description how you discover music, because that's exactly the way I usually do it as well! And thinking about it, the first time I listened to Ludovico Einaudi and Enya was actually in movies. Yes, Pachelbel's "Canon in D Major" is beautiful, I use it as an alarm sound to wake me up in the morning - it's a nice way to start the day. And thanks for "Should it matter" (from Sissel, I suppose), the singer's voice is so beautiful, I had to listen to the song again, and again, and again... Forgive my ignorance, but from which movie is "Should it matter"?

What you describe as your dream, the waves, the wind, the stars, or also a beautiful moon, a colourful rainbow after the rain, all these are wonderful. And the great thing is: These little wonders are there, for us to admire, we just have to open our eyes and see with our hearts... I'm really happy - as you say - to have found a companion in you who can also appreciate these beauties. Well, let's hope that our dreams may come true :-)

Have you watched a sunrise, or sunset, at the sea? I did that when I was in the US. While I was there for my research visit, I had a bit of time left to do a tour through the country, and I was lucky enough to see a sunrise in Miami and a sunset in San Francisco, very beautiful.

Your travel plan sounds perfect. I definitely look forward to meeting you again :-) Please let me know once you have news concerning your visa, or once you have booked your tickets. By the way, since the train from London to Reading is a local one, it's maybe the easiest if I book that for you. If you want, I can do that once you've booked the big trip from France to the UK.

Remember when you taught me this character, 犇? You'll definitely make a very good Chinese teacher. And thinking about how you said to me before on my last evening in Wuhan, I'm convinced that you'll also be a very good German student. So, all I hope is that I can be equally good ;-)

Best wishes,
X

Sent: Sunday, May 31, 2015 4:23 PM
To: X L
Subject: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear X,

Although I haven't decided the all the details of my trip, since the train information of September is still unavailable, but most likely, I will take the train at 10:00 from Besancon, then the Eurostar to London in 23th August, and go to Reading in the morning of 31th :-)

My way to choose music is quite "random" actually, sometimes I just run across a piece of music, if I enjoy it very much, maybe I will fall in love with it after that :-) I like Pachelbel's "Canon in D Major", most of the pieces in Tschaikovski's "The seasons", and also Schumann's "Traeumerei"! And I also get a lot good musics from the movies, for example, "Moon river", "Give me some sunshine", "Should it matter", and almost all the musics in Miyazaki's movies composed by Joe Hisaishi... I notice that Yiruma also wrote some pieces to movies, "Kiss the rain" is beautiful.

You are so lucky to have this unforgettable experience in such a wonderful place! And your description makes me enchanted, again! For me, maybe it existed only in my dream, the bird song, the wash of the waves, even the sound of trees swept by the wind, the sky with countless stars... And I really hope that one day my dreams could come true :-) Maybe in Corsica!

If you could teach me German, I will be more than happy. So I guess I will try my best to be a good student :-) And, if you need any help in Chinese or French, I'm always glad to do all the things I can.

Best,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Sat, 30 May 2015 01:06:56 +0200 (CEST)
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear R,

yes, a visa for visit is fine. Concerning your travel dates, you can arrive at any date you like, I'm flexible. I guess you will want to go back to B after Copenhagen, so maybe you can come to London on 22 or 23 August. Just choose a date which is convenient for you, so that you don't have to rush. And for the departure date, I don't need to go back to Germany early, it would be enough if I take a flight on 31 August, in the afternoon or in the evening. If you visit your friend in Reading afterwards, you'll probably go by train. Then you could for instance take a train in the morning on 31 August, so that I can bring you to the station. This way we'll have at least a week.

Yes, I like music, classical music, but really all sort of music. And I'm not an expert, I just enjoy it. If you want some concrete pieces, I for instance like Schumann's "Traeumerei", Debussy's "Claire de lune", Dvorak's "New World Symphony" or Dvorak's String quartet called "American". The composer I told you about is Haydn, he wrote many piano sonatas, most of which I like as well. But I also like popular music, for instance Yiruma or Ludovico Einaudi, and also Enya. What pieces of music do you like?

Talking about music brings back some of my best childhood memories: I was a member of a scout club, and there were camps during the holidays. Usually we went hiking, and at night, we would sit around a bonfire, someone played the guitar and we would sing songs. It was wonderful. I still remember one trip to Corsica (La Corse), where we went hiking. One night, we went to the beach, just lied there next to the sea, the sky was clear, and we watched the stars. I've never seen so many stars, and they were so bright and seemed so close. It was incredibly beautiful. At that moment, I realized how small we are... I've always wanted to go back there again. Maybe we can go there together? Wouldn't that be wonderful, lying on the beach, listening to the waves and watching the stars together. Oh, it's a dream... But it's a very nice one...

People say that German is a difficult language, but I'm sure not for you, since you seem to be talented; I'm still impressed that your French is already very advanced, much better than mine :-) Here is the deal: I'll teach you German, and you help me improve my Chinese and my French. How is that?

Best wishes,
X

Sent: Friday, May 29, 2015 3:01 PM
To: X L
Subject: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Do you like the music in the movie? In fact, the children in this movie, they are real singers from a chorus called Les Petits chanteurs de Saint-Marc, maybe you would like to listen some of their musics. I remember that you told me you had read some biographies of composers, maybe you like the classical music? I'm intersted in it too, but I'm sure you know much more than me, do you have some good recommendaions?

"Neues finden - Neues schaffen", humm, you make me feel like learning some Germany during the summer vacation for a pleasure :-D And I always have a lot plans for my vacation about learning something, like swiming, pick up painting... But none of them has been put into reality yet :-D Maybe because I am always quite busy during the vacation... I hope this time will be different!

Now I'm doing my application for Visa on the internet, and it is necessary to write the exact time of Arriving and leaving, considering you have a vacation with your family in 1th September, maybe you need to go back to German a few days earlier, so I want to ask you what time do you prefer? The conference in Copenhagen end at 21th August, I'm Ok with all the time after that. What's more, I'm applying a Visa for visit instead of work, it that Ok for reimburse thing? I'm asking just to make sure I don't make any trouble for you, after all, it is a personal visit.

Best,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Thu, 28 May 2015 22:56:59 +0200 (CEST)
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear R,

yes, funny, isn't it, I also joked with my sister that one day, I will write a paper with her :-D But, who knows, what sounds far far away might really happen... At the moment, this is a bit like dreaming. As you say, the way is long. That's the case for my sister. But I really hope she will be happy, and that things will work out for her. It's my dearest wish. And I wish the same for you :-)

The project I told you about was actually very recent, we've been working on the book shortly until I left Germany. The book is to be published soon, we've sent the final version to the publisher. As you suspected, it's in German, the German title is "Neues finden - Neues schaffen". Translated it's something like "Find something new - create something new", although that doesn't sound as nice as the original title :-(

Yes, I agree, it's good to plan generously and to allow more time. Just to be on the safe side. Do you have to go to Paris then? I hope it'll be fine. In my case, when I applied for my visa for China, it was a mess. I needed a letter of invitation, and for some reason, the embassy didn't like the first version I got. So I had to get another one. In the end, I had to go to the embassy several times, and the people working there already knew my face and would greet me with a nod :-) Well, I hope that it will everything go smoothly for you. By the way, the visa fee can be reimbursed, just keep a receipt and give it to me afterwards.

Thanks for your congratulations :-) Yes, it's nice to be done with the exams. I look forward to enjoying life. And I already found time to watch Les Choristes. It's a movie with big feelings, I really like it a lot. I'm impressed how people can inspire people, and that being positive and good matters a lot. Also, music can be very powerful. Speaking about that, do you like to listen to music?

Best wishes, und gute Nacht,
X

From: r.x@e.fr <r.x@e.fr>
Sent: Thursday, May 28, 2015 12:12 PM
To: X L
Subject: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear X,

Congratulations that you finished your task so efficiently, now I guess you could enjoy life again!

Your sister is going to a PhD in maths? Oh, that's wonderful! And this is must be a good news for you, I'm happy for you and I also happy for her that she has a brother like you ;-) Now I've already begun to imagine that in the future there would be two professor LI :-) If she could go to Cambridge, that would be fantastic, after all, this is a kind of "dream school" for most of us. And I'm sure that she will do excellent, because that's what she loves. I hope one day I could meet her.

Thank you for the article you sent, I like it, sometimes we can get many things in non-mathematical article written by mathmaticians. And the project you did seems interesting, you did it when you are still a student? You mentioned that your group write a book, what's its name? Althought it will most likely in Germany :-)

Yesterday, I looked up some informations about applying the Visa, it seems that althought the ducuments needed are quite simple, it still takes time to get my passport back, theoretically 30 days. So it will be better to preparing now in case I can't get my passport back before I go back to China.

Best,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Wed, 27 May 2015 19:06:05 +0200 (CEST)
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear R,

I like your picture of mathematics. It actually reminds me of an article of Atiyah, who also compares mathematics with architecture. I've attached it, in case you are interested. Creativity is a fascinating subject, it is the beauty and challenge of mathematics at the same time. When I was in Germany, I took part in a project about creativity. The goal was to write a book discussing this topic from the perspective of all kinds of subjects. There were articles about creativity and biology, creativity and law, creativity and religion, creativity and music ..., and I also wrote something about creativity and mathematics. Moreover, we interviewed scientists and artists about their opinion. It was interesting to compare the roles creativity plays, and we realized that although the subjects are very different, there are common features. For instance that it's mysterious how we get ideas, they seem to come out of nowhere. But really, thinking about it, we realize that there is a long process of preparation (sometimes unconscious); that's what you describe as hard work.

Last weekend, my sister told me that she wants to a PhD in mathematics. It was quite a surprise for me, since last time we spoke, she was uncertain what she wants to do. But now she seems to be really determined. From my point of view, I just want her to find something she loves, any subject really, but that it will be mathematics is of course wonderful. My sister is now finishing her second year, and she plans to do her master in England, maybe in Cambridge. I hope that one day, you'll be able to meet her. I think that you two would have lots of things to talk about, since your situations are somewhat similar; and since your are more senior, my sister could learn something from you :-D

Yes, I just finished marking. This time it was quick: I started yesterday morning, and now I'm already done! Maybe the exam was too easy, or maybe my students really understood something *daydream*, or maybe I really wanted to answer your question with YES, but I was very efficient this time :-) I'm glad it's over.

Great that you like Papillon. It's funny that you mention the end, that's also my favourite part of the movie. I just felt so happy, because he was so determined, and longing so much to be free. Talking about determination, I was also impressed by the part where he is suffering so much in prison, isolated, in a narrow room, with almost no food, but still he wouldn't say the name of his friend. That's true friendship...

No no, you're not making any fuss at all, I'm actually glad that I have someone to tell the story, it's much better than keeping it to myself. And thanks for your warm words, they went straight into my heart, where I will keep them as a treasure. Thank you :-)

Best wishes,
X

From: r.x@e.fr <r.x@e.fr>
Sent: Tuesday, May 26, 2015 3:24 PM
To: X L
Subject: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear X,

Thank you so much for your reply, I always enjoy the way you talk about mathematics, it makes me feel encouraged and even enchanted sometimes:-) I consider doing mathematics as building a house, at first, you should build the fondation, this is something you should do with hard work, then the rest part of the house requires more other elements, like creativity. So I will go my way step by step with confidence.

I am happy that you tell me the story, in case you feel I'm making fuss, I shall say nothing except that: I believe you will do your best :-)

Speaking of old-fashioned, it's funny that this is the word I often use to describe myself, so I am glad I find a companion :-) Compared with kindle, I prefer the real books in fact, I enjoy the feeling of holding a book and turning the pages, which makes me feel tranquil. Anyway, hope you a good luck in the chinatown. By the way, have you finished marking?

I have wathched Papillon this weekend, I really like it, espacially the end of the movie. When he jumped into the sea with a bag of coconut shell, I think he got the real freeness no matter he succeeded or not...

Best wishes,
R

De: "X L" <x.l@q.uk>
À: "r x" <r.x@e.fr>
Envoyé: Dimanche 24 Mai 2015 23:43:14
Objet: Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Re : Re: Merci beaucoup

Dear R,

I strongly believe that you can realize your dream of becoming a real mathematician. People seem to agree that the most important ingredients are hard work, passion and curiosity, and I see all these things in you. Of course there are other things like talent or luck, but these are not in our control. Actually, I never considered myself very talented. Luck I had several times, but everyone will get chances, so that's very normal. Honestly, I don't think that I did anything special, everyone can do it.
